summary: Paul Merson has restarted his row with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was brought on with only seven minutes remaining in his team's 0-0 draw with Burnley on Sunday. Merson initially angered Townsend for writing in his Sky Sports column that 'if Andros Townsend can get in (the England team) then it opens it up to anybody.' Paul Merson had another dig at Townsend after his appearance for Tottenham against Burnley.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to club president Naoki Ogane. The Japan international, who has played for the J-League side since 2013, will join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge this summer. Ogane claims that Chelsea's interest in Muto is not connected to the £200million sponsorship deal they signed with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber in February. FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto (centre) brings the ball forward against Albirex Niigata in March. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane claims that Chelsea have made a bid for Japan international Muto. Muto tussles with Yuji Nakazawa of Yokohama F.Marinos during a J-League clash last month. Age: 22. Club: FC Tokyo. Appearances: 37. Goals: 16. International caps (Japan): 11. International goals: 1. Did you know? Muto graduated from Keio University in Tokyo with an economics degree two weeks ago. Speaking to Sports Nippon, Ogane said: 'It is true that Chelsea sent us an offer for Muto. 'It is a formal offer with conditions. They want to acquire him in the summer.' Muto, who only graduated from Keio University a fortnight ago after completing an economics degree, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he moves to west London. He has earned 11 caps for his country after signing his first professional contract in 2014, scoring once for the Samurai Blue. A £4million deal for the youngster has been mooted, but Muto admit

The passage discusses a large-scale study that found a link between the use of antibiotics in babies during the first six months of life and an increased likelihood of being overweight or obese as toddlers. The researchers suggest that antibiotics may be contributing to the obesity epidemic, similar to how they are used to make farm animals gain weight. The study found that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by the age of two, and children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. The study did not prove that antibiotics caused weight gain, but it did suggest that killing certain gut bugs may increase appetite and free up more food for the body. The lead author of the study warned that the overuse of antibiotics could be an additional factor in the development of excess weight problems. Previous research has also found that babies given antibiotics are at higher risk of eczema and digestive problems. The passage highlights growing concerns about the over-prescription of antibiotics and the potential consequences, such as the development of antibiotic-resistant superbugs.

The passage describes an embarrassing moment when a Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, which was caught on camera. The guard lost his footing and dropped his rifle, and quickly got up as his colleagues marched past. The incident was witnessed by hundreds of tourists who were watching the event.

The A&E networks are remaking the epic miniseries "Roots" about an African-American slave and his descendants, which had a staggering audience of over 100 million viewers in 1977. The new version will air in 2016 and will draw more from Alex Haley's classic novel, "Roots: The Saga of an American Family." Producers will consult scholars in African and African-American history for added authenticity. The remade "Roots" will encounter a new generation of viewers who have witnessed Barack Obama make history as the nation's first African-American president and "12 Years a Slave" win the Oscar for Best Picture, but also widespread racial unrest over police treatment of black suspects in many U.S. cities.

A former royal footman claims that palace aides tried to force him into an orgy in 1978, but his complaints were ignored for months before the police were notified. The incident left him in tears and he left the job the same day. He finally decided to contact palace officials again last year after inquiries began into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s. Police are investigating the claims made by Mr Lawler.

The passage is about an Oregon couple who announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The couple made the video to share the news with their loved ones who live far away. The original song for the sitcom is sung by Will Smith and details how his character grew up in West Philadelphia and moved to a wealthy neighborhood in Los Angeles. The Meeks' parody video features them rapping about their decision to wait longer than two months to conceive and their excitement about having a child. The video was filmed in five takes and the couple plans to make another video after finding out the gender of their child.

The dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind has sold for $137,000 at auction. The dress, a jacket and full skirt ensemble, was worn in several key scenes in the movie, including when Scarlett encounters Rhett Butler and gets attacked in the shanty town. The dress has faded to light gray from its original slate blue-gray color. The auction also featured more than 150 other items from the film, including a straw hat worn by Leigh that sold for $52,500, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland as Melanie Wilkes that fetched $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived on the scene. He suffered from minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

The passage describes a speed camera that was previously enforcing the 30mph speed limit on a residential road in Handsworth, Birmingham. However, it has not been working for over two years, and around 300 similar cameras were turned off across the West Midlands in March 2013. The camera in question was re-pointed, and a spokesman for Birmingham City Council confirmed that they were aware of it. The camera could be removed completely, and there are no plans to include it in the new pilot using digital technology.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas next month as part of the Jamaican team. He is happy to be part of the team and is fit and healthy. The Jamaican team has a long and successful tradition in relays, and Bolt always does his best to make his country proud while wearing Jamaica colours. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced shortly.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates of Barcelona, attended the El Clasico basketball game on Thursday night. Barcelona won the game with a narrow 85-80 victory over Real Madrid. Brazil's Neymar helped his team win against Chile with a score of 1-0. Before the international break, Barcelona was leading La Liga with four points ahead of Real Madrid. Neymar's sister, Rafaella, also attended the game with Neymar. Neymar was distracted during the game as his sister watched on. Neymar's team-mate, Dani Alves, joined Neymar and friends to watch the game.

Italy is facing a surge of migrants from Africa and the Middle East who are attempting to reach Europe. According to the Italian coast guard, a total of 8,480 migrants were rescued from Friday to Monday, with 20 boats in distress. On Tuesday, Save the Children reported that 400 migrants could be missing, citing testimony from survivors who claimed their ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea about 80 miles off the Libyan coast. However, the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident and has not found any evidence to indicate a particular boat capsized. An operation involving boats and planes did not find any survivors, nor bodies, nor any evidence to suggest a boat capsized. The number of migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy has increased, and the Italian coast guard has been performing more rescues to aid these boats. Most migrants recorded this year come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, and they use Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers. Sometimes, the captains and crews abandon the ships, leaving passengers to fend for themselves.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join the club, despite Liverpool's interest in the player. Sanchez has made an immediate impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger believes that Sanchez's ability to adapt quickly to a new environment proves he is one of the best players around. Ahead of the key Barclays Premier League clash, Wenger has been impressed by Brendan Rodgers' development of the team following the sale of Suarez and injury to striker Daniel Sturridge. Despite speculation linking him with Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling, Wenger has moved to play down any talk of a potential summer transfer move for Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins will look to beat the record and hopes to race in front of a sell-out crowd at the Olympic Velodrome. Tickets to watch the event will go on sale from April 19.

Serena Williams, the French Open champion, struggled to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday, which was a real eye-opener for her as the claycourt season gets into full swing. Despite her best efforts, Williams eventually lost the match 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3, bringing her career record over Sara Errani to 8-0. The US team was also defeated 3-2 in the doubles rubber, with Williams and Alison Riske losing 6-0 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta. Williams admitted that the weather conditions made it difficult for both players, but her power proved to be too much. She said that the match was a big eye-opener for her and that she needs to be more prepared for the claycourt season. The US team will have to work harder to get back amongst the elite nations next year.

River Plate are interested in signing former player Radamel Falcao, who has struggled on loan at Manchester United. The club is open to the possibility of Falcao returning to River Plate, which he did for eight years before joining Porto in 2009. During an interview, vice president Matias Patanian expressed his desire to have Falcao back at River Plate.

Ella Henderson, a pop star from The X Factor, has been announced as the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. The 19-year-old singer has been using Batiste dry shampoo regularly and has been photographed in various hairstyles for the campaign. The partnership between the artist and the brand was managed by the MILES agency and the campaign includes a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, Mirror Man.

The passage describes the shock and disbelief of family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was shot and killed by police in Kenosham, Wisconsin, last month. It also mentions that a billboard featuring the officer who pulled the trigger was erected in the town, which has been criticized as disrespectful and offensive. The billboard was paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, which claims that it was meant to thank the community for its support. The investigation into the shooting of Siler is ongoing.

The passage reports that eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. The militants were killed by Iranian forces in the town of Negur, and the Iranian government has asked Pakistan to catch the surviving assailants. A militant group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack, which is an anti-Iranian group that aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. The Iranian government has criticized Pakistan for failing to rein in the terrorists.

The passage discusses the topic of extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects (UFOs) in Japan's political discourse. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has not encountered any UFOs from outer space. The conversation was initiated by former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who asked about the possibility of encountering UFOs and the legal implications of defending against them. The discussion was not the first time Japanese politicians have addressed the topic of UFOs.

A passenger in Hefei, China, was injured after breaking a toilet he was squatting on in an airport terminal. The man, Jin Pai, 35, was standing on the rim of the toilet when it collapsed, leaving him with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. He had been worried about the cleanliness of the seat and was too embarrassed to ask for help. The incident was determined to be an accident, and authorities reminded people that toilets are meant for sitting on, not standing on.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera in her bathroom that police were able to trace back to the man. A Pennsylvania man was arrested after allegedly sexually abusing a girl in her home over a four-year period and filming the girl, now 15, and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. Kevin Rebbie, 56, faces several charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy, the Montgomery County District Attorney's Office said. The investigation began when a 15-year-old girl found a hidden camera under the sink in a bathroom in her Limerick Township home in March, according to prosecutors. She told investigators that Rebbie had been watching her for years when she was undressing and when he believed she was asleep. She added that beginning when she was nine years old up until she was 13, Rebbie would come into her bedroom while she was sleeping and molest her, according to Philly.com. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera that included footage of the girl and others while they used the bathroom, 34 of which showed victims as they showered. Rebbie uploaded the videos, some that included close-up images of children's genitalia, to his computer to view later, prosecutors said. The videos were captured over a three- or four-year time period, according to prosecutors. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, but had purchased the camera specifically so he could record the now-15-year-old victim while she undressed and showedered, according to the Pottstown Mercury. 'I think it's particularly horrific... and particularly for a young child when they think they're in the sanctity of their home, going through their teenage years, to be violated in the way that this young woman was violated it just goes beyond the boundaries of horrific. It's just unfathomable,' Limerick Police Chief William Albany told the Mercury. The relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family is unknown. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is on May 1 and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.

The passage describes a Japanese photographer, Yûki Aoyama, who has created a series of images featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The photographs are from Aoyama's latest book, Daughter and Salaryman, which allows fathers to express their fun side by being a hero jumping the sky. The images show the fathers in sharp suits and the daughters in casual clothing, posing in front of various Japanese landmarks. The photographs have generated interest online for their curious nature.

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has shifted focus to the start of the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially axed by Downton in 2014, has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to regain his place in the Test set-up. The team photo shoot at the KIA Oval comes before the start of the County Championship season, and Pietersen looks in deep thought as he poses for the team photo.

The passage describes the firing and reinstatement of Brazilian coach Ze Maria at Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation. Ze Maria was fired for a poor run, reinstated after Massone decided to give the coaching staff another chance, and then fired again after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former teammate Nabil Dirar believes that Falcao is regretting his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao struggled to reach his previous heights after suffering a serious knee injury, and the club is unlikely to take up the option to make his transfer permanent. Dirar thinks that Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played and participated in the Champions League.

The passage describes a robbery at a Christchurch dairy where a man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask demanded cash from the owner's daughter. The robber took the till and about $1500 in cash and fled the scene. The police are appealing to the public to help identify the suspect.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice in the past month for allegedly having sex with two underage students. The first incident occurred in January, when a 15-year-old student accused Granado of having sex with him in her car on consecutive nights. The second incident occurred in March, when another 15-year-old student accused Granado of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. The abuse came to light after a school police officer learned of a possible relationship between Granado and one of the boys last month. Granado was arrested on March 19 and admitted to kissing the pupil and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year. She was subsequently suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave by school officials. At the time, detectives said they didn't think she had been in a relationship with any other pupils, but just days later, on March 24, officers quizzed a second boy about a possible relationship with her. A spokesman for the police department said: 'There was some discussion, some rumoring, there may have been a second person involved. 'That information came from within the school, and it turned out to be true.' Granado, who is a maths teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was also arrested last month when she admitted kissing another boy, also 15, and letting him touch her breasts. She was booked into Irving County Jail for the second time on Monday, and released after posting a $50,000 bail. It is not known how Granado intends to plead to the second set of charges against her.

The passage describes a video of a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its mouth. The crocodile was seen calmly moving through the marina, and the dog belonged to the local bike shop's owner. The video has been viewed over half a million times online. The crocodile is a common sight in Puerto Vallarta, as the area is home to mangroves where the creatures have lived for centuries.

Steve Bruce is confident he can keep Hull City in the Premier League this season and avoid relegation. They have six games to save their season, including tough fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to several long-term injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton beat Hull 2-0 on Saturday, leaving them just two points clear of the drop zone. Despite the challenges, Bruce remains positive and believes they can take a couple of results to stay up.

A teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom for two years after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers, invalidating the school's SATs results. The teacher, Ian Guffick, altered some of the pupils' exam answers himself before the papers were sent off. The school officials were tipped off, leading to an investigation by the local education authority. The probe found that some pupils had changed their answers outside exam conditions, and Guffick had done the same. As a result, the Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the entire school last year. Guffick was later forced to give up his job and admitted the allegations, accepting that his conduct amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. The panel chair, Martin Pilkington, said that while Guffick's conduct was dishonest, it fell short of fraud or serious dishonesty. Guffick was banned from the classroom for at least two years, and he deeply regretted his actions.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish international goalkeeper, tied the knot with Swedish model Missse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year. Despite struggling for minutes at Manchester United, Lindegaard enjoys a spot of sunshine with his stunning wife. The couple has a son together and Lindegaard regularly posts pictures of Beqiri on her Instagram page. Lindegaard and Beqiri have been dating since 2012 and have been married for over a year.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once lit the Bronx from above Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at an auction at Sotheby's on Wednesday. The only bidder was a Sotheby's employee trying to jump start the bidding, and the current owner of the signage is Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium saw its final game in 2008. The letters had been installed in 1976 and taken down in 2008, and the auction also included a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s. Despite the Mets memorabilia being estimated at only $20,000 to $30,000, it raked in a winning bid of $112,500 at auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities and urged them to learn from a chastening week. Sterling, the England international who will lead Liverpool’s line at Wembley on Sunday in the absence of the injured Daniel Sturridge, was exposed for inhaling the legal high nitrous oxide on Monday. Then 24 hours later pictures emerged of Sterling and Ibe with shisha pipes. Raheem Sterling (right) was pictured smoking a shisha pipe with team-mate Jordon Ibe earlier this season. Liverpool boss Brendan Rodgers (left) hasn't disciplined Sterling or Ibe for the incident. Ibe was present among the Reds squad during their training session on Friday ahead of their FA Cup semi. Rodgers, who has Steven Gerrard available for the FA Cup semi-final with Aston Villa, spoke to Sterling and Ibe in his office on Thursday but neither will be disciplined and Rodgers now wants to draw a line under the matter. He said: ‘It is understanding that when you are a professional, elite sportsperson, there are things you can and cannot be doing and be seen to be doing. ‘It’s not just for your welfare but also because of your responsibilities. ‘It’s difficult. Some of these young guys are doing what you would consider to be normal things — and I’m not talking about this instance — (but) how it gets framed is totally different.’ Rodgers would not discuss whether he would give Gerrard, available after a three-match suspension, an immediate recall against Villa, making it clear that his sole priority is steering Liverpool into their first FA Cup final of his reign. They fell short in the title race last season and then faltered in the last four of the Capital One Cup in January, but Rodgers thinks they are ready to progress. Reds have captain Steven Gerrard (centre) back for their FA Cup semi after serving a three-match suspension. ‘When you get so close, whether it was in the title rac

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil returned to London after the international break and posted a picture on Twitter relaxing with his dog. Ozil impressed on international duty as Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier on Sunday. He is now setting his sights on the Premier League encounter with Liverpool at the weekend. Ozil has been doing the business on the pitch since returning from injury, scoring three goals and providing four assists since January. He says he is finally adjusting to English football and fits in perfectly.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the La Liga leaders have no plans to replace Luis Enrique and are satisfied with his performance. Enrique, who took charge of the club last summer, is only six games away from winning the title. Despite speculation this season that Enrique will be replaced in the summer, Bartomeu has refuted these claims and is impressed with how the manager has performed. Enrique's side comfortably defeated Valencia in the Champions League, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long-term contract with Liverpool, extending his stay at the club until 2020. He will be worth around £100,000-a-week and will replace Steven Gerrard as the club's captain when he departs this summer. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a full back who signed a three-year contract with Chelsea in July, has struggled to establish himself in the left back position at Stamford Bridge. Atletico Madrid is considering re-signing him, but Luis insists he wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract. He played in Brazil's friendly wins against France and Chile during the international break, but now the focus is on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is determined to keep his team focused and win every game, and Luis is prepared to face the challenges ahead.

Nathan Hughes, a player for Wasps, was initially suspended for three matches after accidentally knocking out George North during a game. However, his ban was overturned on appeal, following criticism and outcry on his behalf. The incident occurred on March 27, when Hughes' knee collided with North's head as he crossed the line to score a try. North was left unconscious and had to be taken off the field on a stretcher. Hughes had previously been knocked out twice in the space of two months. The slow-motion footage of the incident led to some observers condemning Hughes, but many others spoke up in his defense. Wasps were incensed by the suspension and many outside the club shared their dismay. The appeal panel concluded that no foul play took place and Hughes was free to return to action immediately.

The passage describes how the raging wildfires in Siberia caused a dramatic red sunset in parts of the Pacific Northwest. The fires were started by farmers burning grass in their fields, but quickly grew out of control due to strong winds. The smoke from the fires was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean and brought to the Pacific Northwest, resulting in intense red sunsets. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors from the sunlight, allowing red and orange colors to penetrate the air unfiltered. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the fiery sunsets will lose their red hue.

Becky Schoenig, a Missouri mom, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway on Monday night, just over a month after she took it home. On April 1, police found her car after receiving a tip from a man who recognized it and would return it to her, but with some minor changes. The car had been spray-painted red, had red detailing on the sides, and a new orange steering wheel. Schoenig was initially upset but took to Facebook to thank the car thieves for pimping out her vehicle. She also posted a photo of the car, which many thought was a joke. The car had a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, so Schoenig is getting it professionally cleaned. She is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who located her car, Mick Sexton. Schoenig is a vibrant and happy person who loves making people laugh.

Manchester City players will lose £500,000-a-man in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The Premier League title holders give star players like Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart and Yaya Toure incentivised contracts to make sure the club stay within financial fairplay requirements and they will miss out on a big payday if City fail to reach the group stages of Europe's top competition.

The passage describes a friendly match between Manchester United's Under 18s and Altrincham, where Manchester United won 1-0 with a free-kick from Callum Gribbin. The match was played at Altrincham's home ground, which has a capacity of 6,000. Manchester United's Under 18s coach wanted to give his players a similar experience to what they would face in the senior team. The passage also mentions that Manchester United is two points behind Middlesbrough in the cross-town league, and that City has lost both of their play-off matches. The passage suggests that there are many talented young players in the area who may have a chance to play for the senior team in the future.

Joe Hart, an England ace, has praised Gianluigi Buffon, an Italian goalkeeper, as a 'legend of the game' after seeing him claim his 147th cap. Hart, who has represented his country for the 50th time, said Buffon was an inspiration and that he still had a lot to learn from him. Buffon, who is 10 years younger than Hart, revealed his delight at receiving his 50th cap at the Juventus Stadium.

Chipotle has partnered with Postmates to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, with a nine percent service charge. The fast-casual chain has previously turned down offers of collaboration with third-party delivery services, but has now given Postmates the green light. The app hires independent contractors who drive their own cars in a similar model to Uber taxis. Chipotle has gone from strength to strength in recent years and has seen presidential candidates such as Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton frequent their restaurants. Other franchises, such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, have also launched delivery services.

The passage is about the parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, who are urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for the man convicted in the case. They say that the death penalty would prolong their suffering and that they would rather see the defendant spend the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release. They also say that they understand the severity of the crimes, but they want to move on and rebuild their lives.

The passage describes how a custom-built Boeing 747 has been transformed into a luxury home for a wealthy individual, complete with bedrooms, lounges, and an onboard restaurant. The plane, which would typically carry 600 passengers, was built for just one person and features a large dining room, sleeping quarters, and a conference room. The interior is opulent and exclusive, with porthole-style windows and over-the-top decorations. The plane is one of the most luxurious private jets ever built, with a price tag of £400 million.

SpaceX successfully launched a two-stage Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed cargo spacecraft called Dragon to the International Space Station. The rocket landed on a floating barge, but tipped over, and SpaceX plans to keep trying to land rockets on the ground to reduce costs. The Dragon will deliver supplies, including research equipment and ISSpresso, an espresso maker for astronauts, to the space station. The space station crew will unpack the Dragon and send it back to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments, trash, and other items.

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at an all-new chapel of love in Las Vegas. The winning couple, announced next Monday, will tie the knot at Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel on Thursday, April 23. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of the singer's artifacts outside his iconic Memphis, Tennessee, home. The winning duo will win a free wedding reception and hotel suite for two nights, airfares and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. No impersonators are allowed.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team could catch Manchester City in the Barclays Premier League after a tough and long season at Anfield. Henderson and Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in the 2-0 win over Newcastle United on Monday night, equalling the record for appearances by any player in the top five European leagues so far this campaign. However, Henderson thinks that after finding winning form again following poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, Liverpool can put pressure on City who sit four points above them in the race for the Champions League.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A on Saturday in a key match for Champions League places. Miralem Pjanic finished off a swift counter-attack for Roma in the 25th minute and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis did the rest - saving shot after shot by Napoli in the second half. 'It's important to win a match and gain some continuity,' De Sanctis said. Miralem Pjanic slots home to put Roma ahead in the 25th minute after a clinical counter-attack. Pjanic (second left) celebrates with his team-mates Juan Iturbe, and Daniele de Rossi after scoring. Second-place Roma moved provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, who play later on Saturday. They had gone seven matches since their last home win - a 4-2 victory over Inter Milan on November 30. Meanwhile, Napoli's winless streak - home and away - was extended to five matches, and Diego Maradona's former club remained fifth. Security was tight for Napoli's first visit to Roma since a fan of the southern club died following a shooting before last season's Italian Cup final at the Stadio Olimpico. Napoli manager Rafa Benitez shows the strain after his side failed to win for the fifth straight game. Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and fellow forward Gervinho but Pjanic quickly made an impact with a free kick from 30 meters that sailed just wide of the post. A few minutes later, Juan Itu

The passage describes Doncaster Rovers' uninspiring campaign in League One, their goalless draw against Fleetwood Town, and the challenge faced by the media team in sticking up the match highlights on the club's YouTube channel.

The passage describes a man who has a unique relationship with his pet blood parrot cichlid. He interacts with the fish through touch, giving it massages and playing with it daily. The fish is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid and was first bred in Taiwan in 1986.

The passage describes the return of Ben Stokes to the England cricket team after breaking his wrist in the previous year. Investing Solutions, a company that finds properties for homeless men, has been receiving benefit payments from the government over the past two years. The passage discusses a study conducted by University of Edinburgh researchers that found children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. Girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime, the authors said. The findings from the Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime have been published in the latest edition of the Scottish Justice Matters journal. The study has tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 to better understand changes in their behaviour and lifestyles. The passage describes the stabbing of Mr Haugh in the Marian estate in Kilkee, County Clare, Ireland. Hawick Knitwear, a company that employs over 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters to meet demand. The company's sales of the Hawick Knitwear-branded range have been better than expected since its launch in January. The company, which has been in business since 1874, was bought by Benny Hartop in November last year. In addition to the new range, the company has seen growth in its longer-established business of supplying customers who sell the garments under their private labels. Hawick Knitwear sells its products in Europe, North America, and Asia. The company has increased its production to 9,500 sweaters each week, from about 7,500 last year, to keep up with demand. He is confident that the company's success will continue in the future.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, last December. The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, will gather evidence from pensioners and their loved ones to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, saw a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to June 2016, despite a decrease in turnover by £1m to just over £100m. International sales grew over the year, both in Europe and in new markets. The company is confident that it will be well positioned for whatever business challenges Brexit may bring about.

The body of a man in his 70s was found in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was also taken to hospital. Detectives are questioning Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. The investigation is still in its early stages, but the death is being treated as murder. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying hair and average build. He was wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. Anyone with information is urged to contact police or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols have been conducted in the area to provide reassurance to residents.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, warned of risks to the global economy in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics in Washington. The IMF's latest reading of the global economy shows a weakening baseline, and the comments come after weaker-than-expected trade figures from China. The IMF is likely to downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth in April. The dismal picture has ongoing ramifications for businesses and industries that rely on China's growth story.

The passage discusses the problems surrounding the launch of a new ferry, which has broken down, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors and has provided free crossings until 2 July to allow feedback. The council has also authorized the manufacture of ramp extensions to resolve the issue of vehicles scraping the concrete. Compensation for local businesses is being discussed.

A fatal car crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, involving several vehicles, at 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene, and a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models is an international temp agency for beautiful and talented people. They advertised for a personal assistant with a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called it "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women". The agency's founder Nathalie Jansen said their clients are important and looks are important. Another job advert asks a sexy female driver to drive a Porsche Cayenne for a Knightsbridge-based businessman and polo team owner. Employment lawyer James Lynas said the use of phrases such as "beautiful and attractive" are discriminatory against older women. The agency's website states that first impressions count, but they should act like a business in the 21st Century. Under the 2010 Equality Act, it is against the law to discriminate against anyone, including specifying clothing sizes.

Mahesh, an office assistant at the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, was accused of shooting two students, Gautami and Sirisha, in the head with a pistol on Tuesday evening. Gun crime at schools and colleges in India is very rare, and it is not clear what prompted the shooting. Mahesh has been remanded until 12 April.

The passage discusses the findings of the advocacy group Glaad, which analyzed the representation of LGBT characters on broadcast television between June 2016 and May 2017. The study's findings are based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series already being shown or for which casting has been confirmed. While the report shows progress, Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis notes that numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to not run for re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The MP was criticized for a loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council, which is now subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. About £10.25m of the loan is missing and the football stand remains half-built. A majority of his party's local executive council said they would vote to deselect him. Mr Mackintosh had previously said he intended to stand for re-election, but now feels it is the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fired a rifle into a car full of teenagers as they left a party in Balch Springs, Texas, in April, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. The officer was fired for policy violations and the trial has not been set. The teenager was described as a "checklist of everything you would want in a player, a son, a teammate, a friend". Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season to help the Seagulls achieve promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. When I have played I've played well, I've put my best foot forward and I've given myself every opportunity to earn a new deal. If there's one on the table then hopefully we can thrash it out, it can be done and we can enjoy the summer."

The UK Police Memorial Trust is appealing for £1.5m to construct a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff. The memorial will be dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of the officers who have lost their lives over the past 250 years, and will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out for the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial, which is expected to be completed by 2019.

United remain 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. The passage discusses the tax arrangements of Google, which paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. The NHS Improvement wants to reduce the agency bill by £1bn by the end of this financial year. Information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust will also be collected, and there will be scrutiny of those earning large sums from agency work.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs found that the number of plastic carrier bags in England has increased by 200 million since 2013. In an effort to reduce the number of bags being used, from October people in England will have to pay 5p for their plastic bags. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where people are already charged for carrier bags, have seen a decrease in bag usage. Campaigners hope that the charge in England will help reduce the amount of bags being thrown away and benefit the environment.

The passage describes a series of events that occurred in Wales on Friday, including a school roof being ripped off, power cuts affecting hundreds of homes, train delays and speed restrictions on major bridges, and Irish Ferries cancelling sailings due to adverse weather conditions. The Alexandra Palace is a historic theatre that was founded in 1875 and is now being restored to be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios at the eastern end of the Palace will also be repaired and refurbished. The project is being funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, Haringey Council, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m, and the theatre will reopen in 2018. The theatre still has much of its original decor and stage machinery in place.

The passage describes the career of former Manchester City player, Sam Milner, who has won 61 caps for England and holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player. He played three minutes at Euro 2016 and made his senior debut in 2009. Milner also scored his only international goal in England's victory over Moldova at the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family were awakened by their house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, engulfed in flames. They were able to escape, but their house and pets were destroyed. The community has rallied around them, donating clothes and shoes, and even a bike for David. Mrs Smith is proud of her son and will tell him for the rest of his life what he did.

The passage discusses the potential takeover of West Ham United Football Club by energy drinks giant, with a reported offer of £200m. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but stated that he and Gold intended the ownership to pass on to their children.

The Oscars were not held this year, and the ceremony was also used as a promotional platform for upcoming blockbusters. Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes each day over the next four months. Extra staff will also be repairing drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters due to heavy rain.

The incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform in December 2016, where six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of NORM (naturally occurring radioactive material). The workers were not wearing proper PPE and were told there was a problem two-thirds of the way through the trip. EnQuest advised the HSE of the matter, and additional precautionary steps were taken. Wood Group downmanned the employees and conducted medical assessments. The HSE has not investigated the incident as it was not reportable under the present RIDDOR system.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from a New York dealer in 2007, but later admitted selling stolen Indian antiquities. The sculpture was thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India, and the ASI requested its return. ACM returned the sculpture after discussions with the Indian government body looking after its antiquities, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May. ACM will take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

The magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at a depth of 15.5km (9.6 miles) 35km north of the city of Lucca, Italy. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence, and there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy is prone to earthquakes, and in 2009, almost 300 people died in a quake in L'Aquila. The latest tremor was described as a "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" earthquake for the area. The group of scientists and an ex-official who gave a falsely reassuring statement about the danger of the tremors felt ahead of the 6 April 2009 quake were convicted of multiple manslaughter.

The passage describes Austin Grant's experience growing passionfruit in South Yorkshire, despite initial doubts about the climate's suitability. The fruit is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe for consumption.

Rockstar has announced that the release of their game, Grand Theft Auto V, has been delayed until 24 March. The game was originally set to go on sale on 27 January, but the company has decided to extend the release date to allow for additional testing and polishing. The company has assured fans that the extra weeks will be worth it when the game finally arrives in March. In the meantime, Rockstar has announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release date. The company has also released screenshots from the PC version of the game, which will feature greater levels of detail and support for up to triple monitor configurations. While waiting for the game to be released, players can ensure that their PC meets the minimum specifications required to run GTA V. The game was a huge success when it was released on 17 September 2013, generating $1bn in revenue in just three days.

The 76-year-old artist, who received the £25,000 prize for Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, was one of the shortlisted artists in 1991. The painting depicts a leper squint, which were holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service and somehow take part. The relatively small size of Squint (19) was one of the reasons Simpson entered it into the competition, though he also admitted that it "seemed to be a good idea to send one that I was conversant with and was working with". The prize money will be spent on "stretches, canvas and - particularly - good quality paints". The painting is a little bit like a tone poem, with its subtle and minimal language building a picture of great sympathy towards the subject matter. The John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The daily Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, both supporting the AK Party, were attacked by masked assailants who fired gunshots at their buildings. No casualties were reported, and the police are currently investigating the incident. The two papers are located 20km apart, and the attacks occurred early on Thursday morning. The 24-year-old Marcus Bignot, who was under contract with the Stags, has been transferred to Crawley on loan for the first half of the season. He will officially join the Mariners on 1 January.

The passage discusses the potential appointment of Arsene Wenger as the new manager of the England national football team. The passage describes a local man who fell from a cherry picker while working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road in Lincolnshire. The Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that will end the long-running dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had claimed that some workers on board two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay have been operated by Seatruck, which is contracted to run the service by Serco Northlink. Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined to accept. The new arrangements will come into force early next month subject to some financial and regulatory details being finalised. All crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage under the new charter basis. Serco Northlink was awarded the six-year contract in 2012 and operates three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles, which is heavily subsidised by the Scottish government.

The passage describes the death of Ken Dickie, 64, who died in hospital six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, of Apple Close, was found guilty of common assault and attempted perverting the course of justice after an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother. The trial revealed that the two had been in a relationship for several years and were going through a "down phase" when Mr Mitchell visited his mother at the park on 7 May. The evening before the incident, Mr Mitchell and his mother had a confrontation outside the park bar and were separated by members of the public. Mr Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and attempted perverting the course of justice. The court will sentence him and his mother on 6 February.

Temperton, a renowned songwriter, passed away in London last week at the age of 66 after a brief battle with cancer. He was known as "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile. Temperton's father's influence played a significant role in his songwriting ability, as he used to listen to Radio Luxembourg before going to sleep. In the 1970s, he joined a disco group called Heatwave and wrote several hit songs for them, including Boogie Nights, Always & Forever, and Groove Line. His songs also caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, who asked him to write for Michael Jackson's album Off The Wall. Temperton wrote three songs for the album, including the title track, which became Jackson's breakthrough solo hit. He went on to write three more songs for Thriller, including the title track, which became one of Jackson's signature songs. Temperton's tunes have been recorded by various artists, including Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin, and The Brothers Johnson. He won a Grammy Award in 1990 fo

The passage describes the discovery of ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazil. The team of researchers from Swansea University, Exeter, Reading, and Brazil's São Paulo, Belém, investigated ditched enclosures concealed for centuries by bamboo-dominated rainforest. The function of these sites is still little understood, but they are unlikely to be villages, and it is thought they were used sporadically as ritual gathering places. The research indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems, but rather, humans transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees. The team has likened it to a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products.

The Australian player, ranked 21 in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round. Kyrgios, ranked a career-high 12th in the world, won the Japan Open on Sunday and is closing in on the top 10. He was feeling tired and bored during his match against Querrey, and his success in Japan and the travelling involved in playing at the Qi Zhong Stadium had taken a toll on him. He didn't have the best sleep the night before and the ride to the courts was not great. Kyrgios was fined $1,500 (£984) for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters last year.

The passage discusses the potential benefits of vaccinating against HPV, a sexually transmitted virus, to prevent head and neck cancers. Scientists and charities are calling for the vaccination to be rolled out in Wales, citing an increase in the number of cases among younger people, including men. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student at West Calder High School, passed away on Saturday due to a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. His mother, Allison, shared the news on his Facebook page, expressing her heartbreak and gratitude for his journey. Jak's family collected his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. Jak's family urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. The decision was made after a comparative study by Network Rail, and the preferred location is big enough to allow for future expansion. The council will now start the process of acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale was designated a new town in 1961, but it does not have its own railway station.
The passage describes the discovery of plants in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning. Police found them in an "elaborate grow house" and arrested a man in his late 40s.

The woman was attacked by her ex-partner in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, and was dragged through several streets. The study found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The research, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, eliminated any impact from part-time workers earning less than their full-time counterparts. When like-for-like male and female workers were compared, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also concluded that there was no evidence for the idea that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase because they were more wary of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The research also found differences according to age, with women and men under 40 both asking for and receiving pay rises at the same rate.

The passage discusses the lack of suitable burial sites in Oxford, with two cemeteries still having space but expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council has been searching for a new site for many years but has not found one yet. The only options left are the reopening of family plots, the use of reserved plots, and the interment of ashes. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July will feature a new augmented reality experience for visitors to use an app to access online information from signs and posters on the site. The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse collapsed after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He was treated by veterinary staff before being pronounced dead. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, said: "Episodes such as this are rare, and can occur in horses which have no underlying health issues, and amongst all disciplines of sport horses. "In spite of the rarity of these incidents, as a sport we are determined to do more to understand what causes these symptoms, and whether more can be done to prevent it." In Saturday's race, King George winner Thistlecrack caught Many Clouds close to the finish but the Trevor Hemmings-owned gelding, ridden by Leighton Aspell, fought back to win. Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, which had seen him over-heat and "wobble" on his feet, but the horse had never collapsed before, and had shown no symptoms of post-race ataxia on Saturday. Many Clouds had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime". BBC horse racing correspondent Cornelius Lysaght The crucial words here are "no significant underlying health issues". On more than one occasion, notably after his Grand National success, Many Clouds received treatment for a tendency to 'overheat', but he soon recovered, and his welfare was closely monitored by the authorities as a result. With that fact in mind, questions have been raised as to whether that condition was linked to his death, but this report concludes he was the victim of a haemorrhage rarely seen on the racetrack.

The passage describes the case of a 15-year-old girl who was raped by a 34-year-old man named Davina Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. The NSPCC's Childline service received over 4,500 calls from children in the past year, compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12. The report is being released during Anti-Bullying Week, which is coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance. The group is working with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem. One young person who contacted Childline said they were being bullied by a group of people online and were told to kill themselves. The young person's parents didn't realize how upset it was making them and told them to stand up for themselves or stop playing altogether, but they didn't know how hard that was. Advice given by young people on dealing with bullying includes standing up for themselves and not playing with the bullies anymore.

Israel rejected the resolution, and the Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorising new homes in the settlements. The incident happened on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at around 14:00. Multiple people sustained minor injuries, and the road was closed. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season for Bolton Wanderers, helping them finish second in League One and secure promotion. Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, was a passenger in a van that was hit by a Mazda Premacy, being driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. The family described Mr Luciw, the father of a baby girl, as generous, kind-hearted and a lover of practical jokes. Now he will miss all of her life through no fault of his own." "It doesn't feel as if we have lost him - it feels as if he has been taken away from us," said Mr Luciw's brother Simon. The passage discusses the controversy surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence in women. Two patients quit the original review group due to concerns about a watered-down report. An independent expert, Alison Britton, will examine the process and produce a report on lessons learned. The report concluded that procedures should not be offered routinely and patients should be given information to make informed choices. The government does not have the power to ban the procedures, and the chairwoman of the independent review apologized for failing to unite all panel members. Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes quit the review group due to concerns about the final report, and a consultant also resigned. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, and there are currently 400 women taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura McColgan, a British athlete, broke her own record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow on Wednesday, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan expressed excitement to see her last record broken by Muir, who had earlier raised concerns about whether Muir's race met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts. McColgan had told BBC radio's John Beattie programme that the race needed to be a "genuine race" and may not have been as "Muir had been the only competitor." However, British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. The rules stipulate that if there is no doping control at an event where a British record is set, there is no requirement for the athlete to submit drug tests. McColgan said Muir had what it takes to win world medals, and that her race, which saw her lap other runners, was similar to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago.

The passage describes the results of the show jumping event at the Rio Olympics, where GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, France's Astier Nicolas won silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Fox-Pitt, who had been in an induced coma for 10 months, had a flawless performance in the final show-jumping phase. The passage describes the thrilling final of the Australian Open, where British player Andy Murray defeated Italian player Matteo Berrettini in four sets to reach the last 16. The passage discusses the Ulster Unionists' manifesto, which focuses on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the need for a referendum on how it was handled. The Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will go before the assembly for approval, bringing Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales in terms of automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. The motion in the assembly is expected to contain the same provisions and allow for pardons both posthumously as well as for living gay and bisexual men. The motion will now go forward for consideration by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, finished second in the Scottish 1500m race, setting a new record of 4:19.12. This beat Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and moved Muir to second on the British all-time list. Muir, who also holds the Scottish mile record, expressed her excitement and satisfaction with her performance. She hopes to secure an Olympic place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in June. Muir started her season with an 800m victory in France and will compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm next week. She balances her training with her veterinary studies, having recently completed her fourth year of vet school.

The passage discusses the murder of Mr Litvinenko, a British citizen, in 2006. The suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, were accused of poisoning him with polonium-210, a radioactive substance. The Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, stated that the suspects had no personal motive to kill Mr Litvinenko and that the Russian state was likely to have sponsored the plot. He also mentioned that the Russian state had reasons to want Mr Litvinenko dead. The evidence suggests that the Russian state was involved in Mr Litvinenko's murder, but it does not necessarily mean that President Putin was involved. The suspects left a trail of polonium behind, and they have no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. The suspects are unlikely to be tried for murder, and they remain in Russia. Former Soviet army officer Mr Kovtun has been criticized for failing to give evidence to the inquiry.

The passage discusses the appointment of Steve Smith as the new captain of the Australian cricket team, replacing Michael Clarke, who has announced his retirement after the Ashes series. Warner, who has a history of disciplinary problems, has earned the vice-captain's role and is expected to perform well under the added responsibility. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches that follow the final Ashes Test at the Oval.

The passage discusses the views of Liberal Democrat leader Ed Davey on homosexuality and LGBT-plus rights. Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs. Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving the local authority on Friday, at the end of their contracts. Martin quit road racing after the English rider crashed at the TT and the Fireblade bike had mechanical problems. The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in results declared from Saturday's elections. The passage discusses the lifting of Pakistan's ban on YouTube, which was imposed in 2012 after the US-made film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded. A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 near Thornton, Lincolnshire. The Daggers, who were in League One in 2010, needed a win to stay in the league. The Daggers have League Two's worst goal difference and have conceded 20 more goals this season than they had at this point last term. Victory leaves Orient two points adrift of the play-off spots and comes four days after player-manager Kevin Nolan was removed from his role. The former Reds captain, 36, is to return to his former club as a youth coach in February in what will be his first job since retiring as a player. McManus scored the first goal for Morton with a close-range shot, followed by Ross Forbes' deflected strike that doubled the lead. Kyle McAusland pulled Alloa back into the game before half-time, but another McManus finish and one by Denny Johnstone ensured Morton's comfortable win.

Harry Whitlam, aged 51, was killed in a car accident on August 9, 2013, when Gary Green, 51, of Wakefield, reversed his vehicle into him at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, near Leeds. Green was found to be more than twice the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail for failing to ensure the safety of others. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) found that Green had been walking towards a worker in a closed-off area of the farm when he backed the tractor into Harry. The passage provides a summary of the legal appeal made by Uruguayan football player Luis Suarez, who was initially banned for four months by the World Football Association (Fifa) for biting Italian player Giorgio Chiellini during a 2014 World Cup match. Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August after he chatted online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Yorkshire lost to Surrey by an innings and 5 runs in a T20 match at Lord's. They were reduced to 8-2 before posting a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a stand of 130. The 56ft converted trawler was 6 miles west of South Stack when the crew radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST. The boat was unable to cope with the water coming in and the RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.

The East Cliff in Bournemouth will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. English Heritage strongly objected to the scale of the development, but councillors voted in favour, citing the need to improve tourism and living for older people. Forty-nine residents and the Ancient Monuments Society wrote to object to the demolition, stating that despite being altered, they still "give a sense of the historic character of the area". Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was attacked and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, in Brecon, Wales, on May 8, 2020. Senior investigating officer Det Supt David Guiney called the attack "a despicable act" that shocked the community. A family tribute described Pte Boyd as an "all-rounder" who had a promising career ahead of him, and that Vallely had created a void in their family that would never be filled. The tribute also mentioned that Vallely had called himself the "hardest man in Brecon" on the night of the attack, but that the community in Brecon had shown their strength and love for the family.

Andrew Travers, the former chief executive of Barnet Council, left the authority by mutual agreement after an error caused voters to be turned away from all 155 polling stations in the borough. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily while longer-term arrangements are put in place. The #prayforjosh social media campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff. It has since gone viral, with the church's senior pastor, Gary Beattie, expressing amazement at the support Josh and his family have received from people all over the world. The campaign began as a way to ask for support and prayers for Josh, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The news shocked his family, but they have received lots of support since then. The poster with the phrase #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood by the A2 within the last week, and it is part of the campaign. The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks in Wales, which has been a historic military site since 1805. The UK will need to negotiate trade-offs with EU member states, and the CFP framework will no longer apply. The passage describes the journey of L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Since carrying the torch on 26 June, he has received thousands of requests on Facebook, but the site limits friend associations to 5,000 per personal page. Despite this, he has been able to walk with the Olympic torch for nearly half an hour with the help of an assistant. His nomination states that his brain injury has taken his speech, but not his personality or sense of humor. He now speaks unaided and is determined to prove everyone wrong. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, and walks with crutches. He is also a patron of his beloved Pilgrim Bandits and raises money for military charities. His mother has been overwhelmed by the support and friendship he has received, and the family has received thousands of post and e-mail requests to visit places with the torch. Facebook's guidance is that if people are receiving this many requests, they have become a public figure and should consider having a page instead of a profile.

The passage discusses the poverty rate in the US, which was 15% in 2011, meaning 46.2 million Americans were in poverty. Real median income of households in the country dropped by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four in 2011 was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% in 2011, the first time there has been an annual rise in the index since 1993. The percentage of Americans lacking health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%, the report also said. Poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010, at 15.1%.

The passage describes the 25-year-old cricketer Jos Buttler, who moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and has a new deal until 2019. He is a talented specialist short-format player who has scored England's fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan last year. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The passage discusses the decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, which are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships, with no proposals to preserve them. Those who registered an interest are finalizing their bids, with viewings set to take place in late February and March. A final decision is not expected until the spring. The passage discusses the history of Fiji, a country in the South Pacific, and its political and economic challenges. Syria is trying to comply with the UN-backed plan to destroy its chemical weapons, but has missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. The country has shipped two shipments of weapons to the Syrian coast, but the second shipment was intercepted by fire from terrorist groups. The Syrian government denies reports that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, but the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims that members of the Islamic Front coalition have freed hundreds of detainees. The prison is reported to hold at least 3,000 detainees, including Islamists, activists, and minors, in horrific conditions. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, and the US has said that so far only about 4% of the stockpile - 30 tonnes - has left the country. Russia, a key ally of Syria, has said that Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. The OPCW, which is overseeing the destruction operation, has admitted that the process has been slowed down by security concerns. Syria is committed to all its agreements, with the OPCW and the UN Security Council, and will implement on time all its obligations.

The passage discusses a celebrity who is appealing against an appeal court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The celebrity has young children and his spouse is also in the public eye. The Sun On Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by the celebrity, but he argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The celebrity had occasional sexual encounters with another person, referred to as AB, starting in 2009. They had a text message exchange in December 2011 in which they discussed a "three-way" with AB's partner, CD. The three met for a three-way sexual encounter in January. The two other parties approached the Sun On Sunday with the story, and a High Court judge refused to impose an injunction barring publication. The man appealed and two appeal court judges ruled in his favour, preventing him from being identified in publications in England and Wales. On Monday, the judges ruled that PJS was now unlikely to be able to get a permanent injunction, as the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost." The celebrity's solicitors had been "assiduous" in monitoring the internet and removing stories in breach of the injunction, but the judges said it was now a "hopeless task."

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the release of the live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" in Malaysia.
