Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan said fear of eviction and living in poorly maintained properties are common concerns for HMO tenants. Mandatory licensing for HMOs is aimed at houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licenses affect properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling, Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett. The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

The passage discusses the political situation in Ireland, where the two main parties, Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil, are trying to avoid a second election. They have agreed to form a minority government, but disagree on water charges, which are a major issue. They are also considering a commission to review Irish Water, the national water utility. The passage mentions the previous election results, which showed that no party had a majority.

The Sorrento, a ship travelling to Valencia, caught fire and quickly became uncontrollable. Passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. Three people were injured and taken to hospital by helicopter. The ship was about 27km from Mallorca when the fire broke out on one of the car decks. The reason for the fire was unclear. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were sent to help. The rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca and were expected to arrive at the port in a few hours. Psychologists were being asked to provide counselling. The ferry, owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, sent out distress signals and the captain initially did not believe it was necessary to abandon the ship. However, the fire became too intense and a full evacuation was called for.

The Electoral Commission has reported that 38 MPs have highlighted people claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offence. The Commission is calling for better joined-up individual electoral registers to help identify duplicate entries. Labour has warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote. The turnout for the 8 June election was the highest since 1997, with a record number of 46.8 million people registered to vote. However, concerns remain over the number of duplicate applications, which could be as high as 30-70% in some areas. The Commission is calling for clearer information on registration sites and a verification function to address this issue. Despite efforts to discourage people from registering more than once, the Commission is taking the issue seriously and anyone with information shoul

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, was found dead in his prison cell after being accused of killing his former cellmate. He had a troubled past, including multiple convictions for assault and was serving a term of more than 30 years. His coach at Nebraska described him as an intelligent person with good qualities but with anger issues that he couldn't overcome.

The passage describes the promotion of Private Derby XXX, a ram who is the mascot of the Mercian Regiment, to the rank of lance corporal. He was awarded his honour by the colonel of the regiment and is the 30th in a line of mascot rams. He joined the regiment in 2014 and has his own army number, gets paid to buy his rations, and takes his holidays during the mating season. He has also participated in various events, such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

The UK government has expressed its intention to keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about negotiations. However, the Scottish government has called for greater transparency from the UK government regarding its strategic intentions. The UK government plans to hold monthly meetings to share analysis and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views. The Scottish government has emphasized the importance of remaining in the single market for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government hopes to have the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered overruled on appeal to the Supreme Court, but the Scottish government intends to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

The passage discusses a study conducted on 13 cloned sheep, including Dolly the sheep, who were born in 1996. The sheep were clones of the same adult ewe and were genetically identical to Dolly. The study aimed to determine if the cloned animals aged normally and if they were healthy. The sheep were closely monitored and underwent various tests, including joint X-rays and fMRI scans, to assess their health. The results of the study will be published next week.

The passage describes the outcome of the Epsom Oaks, where Shutter Speed, a 14-1 favourite, won by a length and three quarters. She will now compete in the French Oaks, while her stablemates Enable and Coronet are top contenders for the Epsom Oaks. Trainer John Gosden will walk the course before deciding whether to run Cracksman in the Derby trial. The gap between the Dante Stakes and the Derby is just 16 days.

The passage discusses the recent fluctuations in the value of the pound against the dollar and euro, as well as the volatility index, which measures investors' uncertainty. The Leave campaign argues that the pound has simply returned to its March levels, while the Remain campaign claims that the chances of a Remain vote have decreased. The passage also mentions the impact of Brexit on trade and the UK's economy, with some experts predicting a further decline in the pound and a potential economic downturn. The passage concludes by noting that the markets have been affected by global economic worries and that the outcome of the referendum is still uncertain.

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. They lost to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Cowley, the manager, remained positive and said they were a part-time team facing their toughest challenge yet.

The passage discusses the potential changes to the planning system in Northern Ireland, where local councils will take on the responsibility of making planning decisions, instead of the Planning Service. The move is seen as a positive step towards democratizing the system, but there are concerns about the skills and transparency of the politicians involved. The past history of discrimination in public housing allocation and the potential for close relationships between developers and political parties are also mentioned as potential issues. The passage also highlights the importance of transparency in political donations and the need for a law to shed more light on this matter.

The passage describes the shooting of a one-year-old cat in Scotland, which resulted in the amputation of its left back leg. The cat was "incredibly lucky" to survive, and its owners are calling for the person responsible to be found. The Scottish government is considering licensing air weapons, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information to contact them.

Benteke, a 24-year-old Belgium international, has joined Liverpool on a "long-term contract" for £7m from Genk. He scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa after signing from Genk in 2012. Liverpool, who sold Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m last week, triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract to make him their seventh summer signing. The Reds struggled for goals last season following the sale of Suarez to Barcelona and injury absences for Sturridge. Benteke's signing is expected to revive the Reds' attack, along with the signings of Ings, Firmino, and Origi. Benteke missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October and scored 15 times to help Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Anfield, and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is excited to see him lead the Liverpool forward line.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. The study looked at a representative sample of 671 state and independent schools and found that many pupils reported taking an internet-connected device to bed to continue social media conversations. The rapid growth of tablet computers in the classroom was one of the ways in which young people are immersed in technology at school and home. Tablets are now being used, at least to some extent, in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. However, researchers found examples of much more intensive use, with 9% of schools having an individual tablet device for every pupil. The highest use of tablet computers was within academy schools, much greater than in independent schools or other types of state schools. The underlying trend is for an increasing number of tablet computers in schools, with 45% of schools reporting that they would soon be likely to introduce them. While it is not possible to make a definitive connection between tablet computers and improve

The exhibition Growing Up in the City at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 evocative photographs that capture the life of children over more than 100 years. The pictures provide a snapshot of childhood and a thought-provoking social history of life in Liverpool through the decades. The oldest image dates back to 1887 and shows the Rollo family dressed up for a fancy dress ball hosted by the Mayor and Mayoress of Bootle. The exhibition has been curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool, who chose the final 25 images from hundreds of postcards, photographs, and glass plate negatives in the National Museums Liverpool's collections. The exhibition reminds us of the good and bad experiences of childhood, including the children who had to work throughout their childhood.

The passage discusses the recent transfer of striker Myles Keating from Port Vale to Barrow, with the recommendation coming from former Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating, who has played for several other clubs, is described as a young and hungry player who is eager to prove himself. Barrow, who are currently in the National League, have cancelled their contract with centre-back Anderson by mutual consent. The Gulls are currently struggling in the league, with only one win in their last six games.

The new law in Bolivia, signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, permits 12-year-olds to work for others with parental authorization. The law also sets harsher punishment for violence against children, including a sentence of 30 years in jail for child homicide. The measure was approved by Congress earlier this month and signed into law by Mr Garcia in the absence of President Evo Morales, who was traveling to Brazil. The law reflects the needs of Bolivia, one of the poorest countries in South America, and aims to eradicate extreme poverty. However, the International Labour Organization (ILO) is studying the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

The passage describes the story of 50-year-old actress Rosie O'Donnell who experienced a heart attack while helping a woman in her village. She initially searched for symptoms online and took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a blocked artery. O'Donnell wrote about her experience on her blog and urged her readers to be aware of the symptoms of a heart attack. She also mentioned that her talk show was cancelled due to low ratings.

The passage describes the stabbing of a 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington, at a party in Kenton, London. He was stabbed in a scuffle with a group of youths who tried to gain entry to the party. He was pronounced dead about an hour later. Two other boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested on suspicion of murder and possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage discusses the implementation of a new approach to diagnose cancer cases in Denmark, which has resulted in better survival rates. The approach involves three routes: fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with vague symptoms, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The changes have not led to an increase in GP referrals but have improved the organization of patient diagnosis within existing resources. Denmark's health system is similar to Wales, and there may be lessons to be learned on how better organization can improve cancer diagnosis.

The passage discusses the creation of a new team in Powys council to handle complaints against estate agents. The team will issue warning and banning orders against agents who act dishonestly or breach estate agent laws. The move follows the disbandment of the Office of Fair Trading. People can still contact their local authority trading standards department for prosecution. The new team will be led by James Munro and hopes to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

The NHS Employers has given the green light to a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce to help cover for doctor shortages and cope with the rising number of patients. The plan involves nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs, but unions warn against using it as a quick fix for problems in the NHS. The report highlights examples of areas already experimenting with reshaping the workforce, including covering for doctor shortages and providing more rewarding roles for staff. However, the Nuffield Trust admits that money will need to be set aside to ensure it happens. The report author Candace Imison says there are "huge opportunities" in reshaping the workforce to improve patient care and provide staff with more rewarding roles. NHS Employers chief executive Danny Mortimer agrees and says the challenge now is to take forward the learning and recommendations in the report. However, British Medical Association leader Dr Mark Porter warns that increasing the skills of the workforce should not come at the expense of good quality training for doctors. He says there is no substitute for the expertise and experience of doctors, and that there should be more staff support for doctors to coordinate the best possible care for their patients. Unison head of health Christina McAnea says the squeeze on funding in the health service means there is often no funding for training courses. She adds that developing the NHS support workforce must not be seen as a quick and cheap fix for chronic shortages of nurses and other health workers across the country.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot after a collision at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. Investigations are underway into the cause of the accident. First resumed normal services, but it will take a few hours for all services to return to normal. The managing director thanked the public for their support and understanding and staff for their efforts.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding the Swansea tidal lagoon project, which NRW estimates will result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying each year. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming they have no scientific basis and that NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating them. TLP's computer modelling suggests a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species being killed. The UK government is considering the viability of the project, and Wales' Environment Secretary is supportive but wants clarity on the government's position. NRW disagrees with TLP's criticism and is confident in its evidence.

The passage discusses the announcement made by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster, regarding the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland. The body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will play a pivotal role in providing strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The move is seen as a positive step towards better coordination of current marketing activities in Northern Ireland, but it may have implications for the work of other organizations, including the Agriculture Minister's department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting project at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. The project aims to plant 40,000 native UK trees and is one of the trust's most ambitious planting programmes. The charity is inviting local people and visitors to get involved and make a mark on history through the simple act of tree planting. The charity is providing the saplings for members of the public to plant, and has advised volunteers to wear welly boots or "stout footwear".

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate on Thursday. The book, Someone Else's Skin, is a thriller that tackles domestic violence and so-called honour crime. The author, Det Insp Marnie Rome, was able to conjure up atmosphere in very few lines. The other books on the shortlist were Sara Paretsky, who received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago, and Kathleen Turner, who played VI Warshawski in a 1991 movie based on the Deadlock novel and in a BBC Radio 4 adaptation. VI Warshawski was "a real game changer", Cleeves said, as she changed the way that readers thought about female writers. Paretsky also set up Sisters In Crime, an organisation to support female crime writers around the world.

The passage discusses Santner, a 24-year-old cricketer who broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes stated that losing Santner was a major blow to the team's hopes of qualifying. Santner will rejoin the team in June for the ICC Trophy in England. He expressed his frustration at picking up the injury in the first T20 game and hopes to make an impact next summer. Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, returned to a restaurant for a missing glove and was later found dead. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that Barry's guard was lowered by inebriation and the car had stolen licence plates and did not brake or stop. The case demonstrates the difficulty in investigating a death abroad and the family has endured years of distress and unhappiness. Close friend Peter Clifford, a lawyer, believes there is no reasonable doubt that Barry was murdered. Anna Ziuzina, known as Ganna, tried to claim her husband's assets within days of his death and was believed to have been involved in his death to inherit his money and property. The inquest heard that Anna was a lap dancer and stripper and that she sold her husband's Range Rover, contents from his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. She was also having an affair with a Ukrainian man. Despite attempts to get her to attend the inquest, she did not believe she could add anything further. The Ukrainian police closed an inquiry into his death, but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son Charlie, who has been ill since the age of three, urgently needs more T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital after the last transplant failed. The family was left heartbroken when the first T-Cell transplant did not work. However, they were extremely grateful for the generosity of an anonymous donor who paid for the treatment. The donor specifically asked to pay for Charlie, and the family is overwhelmed by the selfless act. The treatment will start as soon as possible, and the family is expecting to find out the date next week.

The passage discusses the recent hack of celebrities' intimate photos from iCloud, which was facilitated by third-party software. Apple has implemented a new security measure that requires users to enter a four-digit code after logging in from an unfamiliar device. This measure should prevent the tool from accessing iCloud, but it remains an opt-in choice. Apple is considering making two-factor authentication the default option. The process involves entering a code sent to a trusted phone number or via the Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud is denied, and users can regain access with a recovery key. Apple had previously offered two-factor authentication but did not use it for iCloud backup

Dan Groves said the "finer points" of a deal which could see Wright buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points adrift of a play-off place. Wright, who was runner-up in I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, played non-league football for a succession of clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay have recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said shortly after completing a deal for the club that he was "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

The passage discusses the treatment of workers at Sports Direct, a company owned by Mr Ashley, who has been asked to give evidence about their working practices. A letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright reveals that Mr Ashley had invited the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook, but Mr Ashley has not responded to the invitation. The committee has the right to take further action if Mr Ashley fails to agree to attend. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment.

The report, titled Putin. War, was never written but the murdered opposition politician's colleagues, led by his close associate Ilya Yashin, have worked to finish it. The report is based on facts that have already appeared in Russian and foreign media since Crimea was annexed in March 2014 and conflict broke out in eastern Ukraine. The authors argue that the facts make a compelling case for accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. Russia has consistently denied accusations of sending regular troops and equipment to help rebels in eastern Ukraine, but Mr Yashin says Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in securing key victories claimed by the pro-Russian rebels. The dossier presents evidence of volunteer soldiers who admit they were directed by Russian generals to take part in the war. Russian spending on the conflict is calculated at 53bn roubles (Â£665m; $1bn). The opposition will seek donations to extend the initial print run of only 2,000 copies, but publishing and distributing this kind of dossier is difficult due to fear of publishing material that could be dangerous. The report may not see the same fate as earlier works published by the late Boris Nemtsov.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday morning. He died from head injuries and a man and a woman, both aged 41 and 23 respectively, were arrested in Sheffield and are currently in custody.

The passage discusses the disagreement between the Welsh and UK governments regarding the drafting of the Article 50 letter. Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones has complained that he did not see the letter before it was published and was not invited to contribute to its drafting. The UK government has stated its aim to develop a negotiating framework for the whole of the UK, but the Welsh government has expressed frustration with the lack of respect shown to the devolved administrations. The UK government has mentioned Wales in the letter, but it is unclear which powers will be devolved and whether the money will follow the powers.

The passage describes two cars being damaged in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. The PSNI was carrying out duties when attacked, and the post on their Facebook page appeals to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

The passage discusses the ousting of Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, due to employee complaints and misuse of company funds. The board of directors does not expect him to return to the company, and his lawyer has accused the company of invading his privacy. The court filing documents evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts from the former CEO. The board claims that Mr. Charney's conduct violated the company's policies and that it would be too risky to hire him. American Apparel has also obtained a restraining order against Mr. Charney.

The passage provides information about the upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece at the Copper Box in London. The game will be broadcasted on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Three members of the Greek team will not be playing, giving GB a chance to seek revenge. The game is important for GB as it is their only home game before competing in FIBA EuroBasket 2017. The team will also play in a four-team tournament in Poland as a warm-up before the tournament starts in September.

The passage describes the launch of the iPhone in 2007, which revolutionized the way people used their phones and other devices. It mentions how the iPhone had a powerful user interface that attracted many users, and how it enabled new activities such as photography and internet browsing on the move. It also compares the iPhone with the Model T Ford, which was a game-changing product in the early 20th century. The passage concludes by acknowledging the impact of the iPhone and other similar products from Amazon and Google.

The passage describes a series of cat poisonings in Leicestershire, with seven-month-old Meereen being the most recent victim. The cause of the poisonings is unknown, but the RSPCA is urging people to store pesticides and chemicals safely.

The Syriza government is expected to agree and implement more austerity and liberalization measures, despite opposition from the public. Greece's economy is struggling, with a near-death experience in July leading to a standoff with the rest of the eurozone. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to deliver an end to fiscal austerity. The new bailout deal will only hold if creditors ease Greece's unsustainable debts by a significant amount.

Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, will return to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes. Barbara, who had left in 2010, will return to tell her eldest son Phil that her cancer has returned. After the episode, producers revealed that Peggy will die from the disease in emotional scenes to be screened in the spring. Grant Mitchell, who has been one of the soap's most memorable characters, will return to bring the Mitchell family back together.

The passage describes the tragic murder of Alice Ruggles by Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon in October. The police were called to the Hills' home after Dhillon stalked and attacked Ruggles. Prof Ruggles, Alice's father, recognized Dhillon as the killer and felt guilty for not taking the situation more seriously. The family has set up a trust in Alice's memory and hopes to raise awareness about stalking. Dhillon was found guilty and sentenced to 22 years in prison.

The passage discusses the approval of the Hinkley Point project in Somerset by French firm EDF, which is financing most of the £18bn project. The government has expressed concerns about the project's environmental impact and escalating costs, and has launched a review of the project. The project is being built by foreign governments, with one third of the cost being provided by Chinese investors. The government's decision to approve the project has been delayed, an

The newly-designed form for divorce in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse has committed adultery with, but it is not mandatory to do so. Family lawyers are concerned that involving a third party adds conflict and complexity to the process. The Ministry of Justice states that there is no obligation to name the person. Lawyer Margaret Heathcote, vice-chairwoman of family law group Resolution, believes that naming the third party increases conflict from the start. The online form has been updated to make the process more user-friendly, but some people may choose to ignore the legal guidance. The older version of the form allowed for co-respondents to be named, but the new form explicitly asks for the name of the person the spouse committed adultery with. If the petitioner names the third party, they become part of the court case and may incur more costs. Adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces in 2015, while unreasonable behaviour accounted for 46,815. Most clients who seek help with adultery-related matters want to involve their new partner, but it can put the petitioner in a bad light and may delay proceedings. Judges generally do not view petitioners bringing in new partners favorably.

The passage discusses the conflict between the emphasis on the environment and the need for timber in Britain, which is currently the world's third largest importer of wood. Ministers are encouraging commercial forestry organizations to invest in woodland creation, but Confor, which promotes the forestry industry, warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted to meet needs. The Welsh government wants a balance between the environmental, economic, and social aspects of forestry development, and points to its Glastir scheme that encourages farmers and landowners to plant woodland. However, there is a conflict with environmental policy, as ministers want more native, broadleaf species of trees and better access for walkers and bike riders, while conservationists claim commercial forests are bad for wildlife. The Welsh government's Woodlands for Wales forestry strategy aims to enhance the landscape, provide social and community benefits, support thriving woodland-based industries, and contribute to a better quality environment. Martin Bishop, of Confor, believes the emphasis on environmental aspects is seen as "sexier" than commercial forestry, and the current system is too bureaucratic for creating new woodland areas.
The boy was struck by a car in Coatbridge and taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys, who were responsible for resupplying the Soviet Union during World War II. The convoys faced constant danger from German attacks and harsh weather conditions. The ceremony was initially blocked by the Foreign Office, but later allowed an exception to the rules. The medals are a symbol of gratitude from Russia for the Allied alliance and the contribution of the convoys to the war effort.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work and too many were let off if they did not attend. In one case, an offender had completed just 16 hours in 17 months since being sentenced. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's recommendations. Unpaid work, ranging from 40 to 300 hours, may be given for offences like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, or criminal damage. 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work in 2014. Inspectors looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing how often offenders are turned away from work when they report on time and creating objectives for unpaid work that match the circumstances of the offender. The chief inspector of probation called for "urgent remedial action" and the Ministry of Justice spokesperson said they wanted "much more effective rehabilitation" and would take action to implement the recommendations.

The passage discusses the accusations of hypocrisy against comedian Ricky Gervais, who campaigns for economic and political revolution to help the poor, yet lives in a luxury home. The passage also mentions his response to a question about his rent, his previous explanations of his actions, and his views on the need for systemic change.
The passage describes the life and achievements of Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur who revolutionized the field of human genomic

The passage discusses a survey conducted by the School Food Trust in England, which found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of the parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among the children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The survey was commissioned after a survey by the Mumsnet website suggested that some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought they were too fussy to eat anything else. The chairman of the School Food Trust, Rob Rees, said that school meals can be a great way to help parents encourage their children to try new foods and increase the variety of foods in their diet. The survey was conducted online among a panel of parents who had at least one child in school aged 4-17 years old.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish football player, joined Juventus in 2014 from Real after four seasons with the latter. The transfer fee was reported to be up to 30 million euros. Morata, who previously played for Arsenal and Chelsea, has scored three goals for Spain in France. He has scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata played in back-to-back Champions League finals, having appeared as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015. He made his first team debut at 18 and scored 10 goals for Real.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, but has been without a team since being released in May. He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having spent four seasons at the club prior to signing for Celtic. He has also previously had spells with Preston North End and Notts County.

The British supermarket giant, Tesco, is disposing of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, by transferring around 4,000 employees to the new business. The deal involves a loan of around £80m from Tesco and the remaining 50 stores will be closed. The disposal of the Fresh & Easy brand will cost Tesco £150m, but part of that is a loan which may be paid back. Yucaipa, a Los Angeles based private equity company, will run the new business and has the option to buy a stake if it becomes profitable. Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April.

The passage describes how a person initially faced racial abuse but overcame it to pursue a career in martial arts. They briefly considered representing France but ultimately aimed for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

The passage discusses the retreat of glaciers in the European Alps, specifically in the French Alps, over the past 40 years. The area covered by glaciers has decreased from 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to 275 sq km in the late 2000s, with the greatest losses seen in the southern sectors. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the Belledonne Massif experiencing complete glacier disappearance and the Ecrins Massif experiencing more than three times stronger retreat than the Mont Blanc Massif. The northern region, including the biggest French glacier La Mer de Glace, has also seen a decrease in area. Efforts to monitor glacier health are ongoing in the Alpine region.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers to date and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday, securing their place in the finals. However, Scotland's goalkeeper Gemma Fay is determined not to miss out again after previous play-off losses for Euro 2013 and last year's World Cup. The outcome of Friday's match and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September will decide who tops the group. Scotland, ranked one place above Iceland, are in pole position to reach the finals in the Netherlands without the need for a play-off. Iceland, a top seed in the group, are a strong side and Scotland has a good chance to beat them. Having the fans behind them makes a huge difference for the team. Scotland has a diverse squad with players from different countries, including five at English clubs, four in Sweden, and two at Seattle Reign in the United States National Women's Soccer League. The benefits of having more players in the world's top leagues are evident as Scotland gets closer to their first major finals.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish blogger and former computer games reviewer, was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London. The woman alleged that Mr Campbell had harassed her over a two-year period. Mr Campbell, who was released on bail, denied the allegations and accused the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage speculation. Peta wants to replace the Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan Skegness - A Happy Plaice. He is the first inmate to be freed since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. The US opened the facility in January 2002, following the 11 September 2001 attacks in America. President Barack Obama has repeatedly promised to shut it down.

The passage describes a shocking incident where a light general aviation aircraft touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear and skidded along the runway on its belly. The passage discusses the alarming rise in the number of children born with brain damage due to exposure to alcohol in the womb. According to official data, 272 youngsters were hospitalised in England last year with Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS). However, experts believe that the actual number of affected children could be much higher. The World Health Organization estimates that at least one in 100 babies in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure during pregnancy. Tom Poynton, a wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a new one-year contract extension after returning from injury. He missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident in which his father died. Poynton underwent an ankle operation but made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The passage describes a video of a Labrador Retriever named Cooper eating ice cream at a McDonald's drive-thru. Gary Locke, the interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the permanent manager of the club after signing a three-year deal. The passage describes the discovery of an unidentified woman in Brooklyn who died on March 22, 2021. She was found unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. A new Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom, solar-powered home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck. They started the project in 2009 when they couldn't afford to buy a full-sized lot. After a year and a half of hard work, the home was completed in about a year. The couple now lives surrounded by nature, with aromatic cypress wood inside and majestic trees and a babbling brook outside. The home is powered mostly by solar panels and the couple is nearly self-sufficient. They have a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and other creature comforts. Children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests than those who do not, according to researchers. The findings contradict the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, who is skeptical about using technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes. However, research suggests that the best outcome comes from sharing devices. Kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year significantly outscored their peers who used the device on their own or had no iPad. The collaborative learning around the technology made the difference, not just the collaboration itself. Schools might reconsider how the tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to make the technology most effective.

This passage is about a two-legged piglet born with its back legs missing who has become an internet sensation for learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "super pig," has captured the hearts of thousands since a video of it went online. The piglet's siblings were all born with all four legs, but the piglet has to use extraordinary balance to stand on its two front trotters. The piglet is not the first animal with two legs instead of four to win plaudits in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou zoo became a star attraction after learning to walk on its front paws. A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by a car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, revealing that she came close to taking her own life. During a candid interview, she explained how anxiety drove her to believe that she had reached a stage in her life where she couldn't see the point of continuing. Her anxiety brought her to a point where she couldn't see the existential point of continuing, and she felt increasingly isolated. She attributed her struggles to a combination of issues, including mounting stress, anxiety, her thyroid disease, and distant family. While she had not found a husband or children, she felt increasingly alone. However, she has recently found some peace with her anxiety. In her eyes, depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked, and she believes that acknowledging this link is crucial to tackling the increasing rate of Australian women negatively affected by stress and anxiety. She now accepts that she is an anxious person, but when she was younger, she watched others coping and felt like she had missed out on a guide book to life. Beyond Blue reports that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and although depression and anxiety are two different conditions, one can often lead to the other. If you or someone you know needs help, do not hesitate to contact beyondblue on 1300 224 636 or lifeline 13 11 14.

An Oregon woman who beat her boyfriend's former girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in her bathroom will not face prosecution. The woman, Elena Curtin, was seven months pregnant when she was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014. She was set to go to trial in Multnomah County Circuit Court, but prosecutors dropped the charge on Monday, stating that Curtin was justified in her outrage. Curtin gave birth in January and found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom. When she asked her to leave, the woman refused, and Curtin beat her with a crowbar. Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney, Casey Kovacic, said the ex-girlfriend was jealous and bitter that the boyfriend was in a relationship with his client. The boyfriend struggled with heroin in the past, and the ex and boyfriend had gotten high at the apartment before. They have since reconciled, and Curtin is now living with her parents. The boyfriend has not been a part of his new child's life. Kovacic wrote that the ex-girlfriend made it her personal mission to make Elena's life miserable, harassing and threatening to hurt her, stealing from her, and plotting to drag the boyfriend back into addiction. The ex-girlfriend's actions were one silver lining, as Elena was able to examine how bad her relationship was and move on with her life. If Curtin had gone to trial and been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.

hsbc has apologized for directing visitors to a pornographic page on its official website. The link was found on the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneurs Awards, which was shut down in 2011. A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 after a fire broke out on the first floor of his home in Clinton on Sunday morning. The algae, called Noctiluca scintillans, is a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in the spring and autumn and is usually a natural occurrence. It is also a carnivorous cell that gives off a luminous glow as a defense mechanism.

The passage discusses new tests that can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to determine their aggressiveness. After surgery, the cancer cells are screened and women can be informed of their risk of recurrence within days. For some women, the test can accurately predict a low risk of recurrence, which is as good as or better than the odds for those who undergo chemotherapy. Currently, most women with breast cancer receive chemotherapy, but for some, the prospect of the treatment is more daunting than the surgery itself. The newest test, called endopredict, can accurately determine a low risk of recurrence and patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. The tests are available privately and cost about £ 2,500, but breast specialists hope they will soon be available on the NHS. Surgeon Hemant Singhal believes the NHS should use the test to save money on chemotherapy, while Professor Kefah Mokbel believes it can help patients make informed choices. Rebecca Cornford, a mother of three, was diagnosed with breast cancer and found out she had cancer in her other breast. She was told she had a low risk of recurrence and could opt not to have chemotherapy.

The passage discusses the issue of pregnant women serving in the Royal Navy, with over 25 women being airlifted from ships due to pregnancy. Japanese law restricts drone flights around airports, but there are no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including the prime minister's residence and government buildings. However, the WHO warns that doctors are performing the procedure too often and underestimating the risks. Previous research has found that as many as one in ten caesareans cause infections.

The decision was made by the International Association of Athletics Federations Council, bypassing the usual bidding process, due to what they saw as a unique strategic opportunity to host the event for the first time in the US. The decision departs from the usual procedure, but the IAAF president is delighted that his council colleagues understood the opportunity presented to access a key market and have taken a decision in the interest of the global development of the sport.
